review_blob: Murky orange-copper with lots of carbonation and a big white, creamy head. Taste isnt anywhere near a traditional IPA. Has a bit of Belgian sourness working - just a tad. It has characteristics similar to Hopslam, with the citrus and bitterness and a bit of honey bite, but isnt anywhere near Hopslams level. A bit of a metallic taste also. Its OK, but not worth repeating. Note that mine might be a bit old, as it was a bargain bin bomber.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: Lots of roasty grain on the nose. Taste is more deep-roasted grain, some dark chocolate and a little bit of dark roasted coffee. Is quite bitter for a serious stout, which makes it very drinkable. Excellent.

Wow! is likely to come to mind when you smell and taste this for the first time. Big dank and citrus aroma. BIG grapefruit and orange citrus taste, without much earthiness/grassiness, which I was expecting based on the aroma. Very bitter. Really juicy, initially seems like it has some orange juice in there. Great malt balance. After it warms, but ABV becomes more obvious, a bit much for my taste. Still, this is an excellent and VERY big IIPA.

Slightly murky, golden yellow color. Taste is strong pine to start, then citrus with a hardly noticeable medicinal quality near the end. Quite dry, with not a lot of sweetness. Could use stronger malt balance. Bitterness doesnt linger a long time. Its good, but doesnt blow my socks off.
beer_name: Flying Dog The Truth Imperial IPA

review_blob: Murky, dark-golden with a medium white head. Aroma is lost on my stuffed nose. Caramel, a bit of citrus, a bit of crackery malt, fairly mild bitterness. Odd aftertaste and bitterness that lingers. An odd IPA. Not bad, not quite good, but it could be with some minor tweaks, I think.

A bit disappointed in this after discussing it some beer friends. I was hoping for a tropical fruit, citrusy beer, then once we had it in hand, realized its a English ale.. Clear, yellow, golden with a small head that goes away fast. This has citrus - plenty of lemon, but no tropical notes at all. The flavor certainly has the English ale touch to it. Crackery malt. Could use more balance. Nice bitterness, though. Would be better with food, I think. Its not bad, just too lemony for my tastes. No need to have this again.

From a bomber. This is probably the clearest IIPA/DIPA Ive ever seen. Yellow-golden color with a small head. Aroma is odd, I cant quite place it, other than it sure doesnt smell like an IPA. Flavor is more on point, with nice mango, citrus, pineapple, though it needs more malt to balance. Its a lot less bitter than most IIPAs. Its decent, but I certainly dont need to try it again.

I bought a six pack and have powered through most of it. Id normally share one or two with some beer buddies at work, but I wont subject them to this thing. When I opened the first bottle, the watermelon aroma was amazing and made me think I was in for a treat, since I love the taste and smell of watermelon. Wrong. The taste is basically salted watermelon (I dont normally salt mine, though) with a IIPA in the background. That salted watermelon just ruins any good points of Dorado in the background. Its a bit too carbonated, which doesnt help. Ugh...only 1 and 1/2 of these to go....
beer_name: Ballast Point Dorado Double IPA - Watermelon

review_blob: Pine and citrus aroma. Same on the taste, with crackery malt, medium bitterness. Very dry. Hops profile seems complex and Im in a phase where I prefer beers with one or two hops instead of 5+. Its good, but not sure I need to try it again.
beer_name: Firestone Walker Luponic Distortion Revolution No. 001

review_blob: From 12 oz can. Has one of the best aromas of any beer Ive tried. Lots of tropical fruit, citrus, grassy, a bit of funk. I just enjoy bringing it up to my nose every minute or so before taking a sip. Flavor is citrus, earthy, just the right amount of malt sweetness, with pine and citrus rind bitterness and a nice citrus tang/tingle. A great IPA.
beer_name: Surly / Amager Todd - The Axe Man (Surly Version)

review_blob: Fairly sweet, tastes like a better version of Heineken maybe? Fairly sweet, more lemon than I expect from a lager. OK, but I do not care to try it again.

Hmm...seems like another Dogfish Head experiment gone, well, not quite wrong, but not quite good. I get some tropical fruit aroma, but my first thought on the taste was lemon, yeast, like a Belgian, which this isnt meant to be. I go this from a reputable store with high turnover, so I figure this is another instance of me not quite "getting" a Dogfish Head beer.

Hazy yellow color with a really cream medium white head. Taste is resinous with citrus, though more resin on the aftertaste. Malt balance is perfect. Carbonation has some of the finest bubbles, and LOTS of them, that Ive encountered, especially in an IPA. Dry, and super-easy drinking.

Not a style I seek out but had to try it since I see it so often in stores. Plenty of lemony, yeasty wheat beer here, and that interesting coriander thats in the background. Interesting, but not a beer I want to try more than once.

Murky golden yellow with a medium white head. Aroma is lager-ish. Tastes quite malty-sweet for an APA, with mild bitterness and floral notes quite subdued in the background. Its OK, but I dont need to try it again.

Aroma is cereal grain and wet newspaper. Taste is very soapy, astringency, grain...bordering between sort-of-drinkable and pour it down the drain, but more on the positive side of that. Would be better with food as opposed to the way Im having it, on its own.

Very dark brown with almost no head. Roasted grain and caramel aroma. Taste is more of that, plus some sweetness. Surprisingly dry, with a roasted grain aftertaste. Palate is quite light and it seems like it either needs more body or more carbonation. Not bad, but certain not something I want to try again.

Aroma has plenty of citrus. Flavor is citrus mixed with pine and a fairly serious malt backbone, but still being fairly dry. I dont find the citrus overpowering at all, though it is a bit stronger than similar types Ive tried - but I like that. I like this a lot.

That hops profile matched with fairly heavy malt for an IPA is just not for me. Its good, no argument, but not one I like a lot. Some mango and lots of caramel flavor, fairly heavy palate for an IPA. Creamy mouthfeel, fairly dry and not as "juicy" as I was expecting from a tropical IPA. If youre a Founder fan, its worth a try, though.

Aroma is dank. Taste is crazy citrusy and quite sour, with hops bitterness following on. Has a fairly mild malt background. That citrus and sourness from it really jumps out. Dry, bitter finish. Would be great outside on a really hot day...to bad its early March in Chicago and its *!% below freezing :(

Its Sculpin with moderate pineapple aroma initially, but once Ive taken a couple of sips, I detect zero pineapple aroma. Its the same in the taste, but the pineapple taste is barely detectable at the start. After a couple of sips, theres no pineapple taste at all. Its regular Sculpin after that, which means its good, but I was disappointed with how subtle the pineapple is over all.
Typical porter small, tan head and deep brown color. Smells of coffee. Taste is coffee and sweet dark chocolate with a nice dry, bitter finish. Palate is medium for a porter. Excellent porter.

A "light" stout. Roasted grain, coffee aroma. Taste is the same, with some creaminess of the sugars and dark chocolate.  A bit thin for a stout. Just enough bitterness to counter the sweetness. Sweetness is mild. Decent, but not something I want to try again.

Roasty grains, dark chocolate and dark dried fruit on the aroma. Taste is booze, roasted grains, a tiny bit of dark chocolate and a lot of that dark dried fruit, which makes it cloyingly sweet to me. I get some nice hops far in the background. It is an Imperial, after all, so not too surprising, but its odd how my experience differs so much from the norm.
This reminds me a lot of Surly Furious, one of my favorites, but not quite as refined as Furious.

This is almost a session IPA. Palate is a bit light. Aroma is grassy. Taste is citrus and pine. Balance of malt is quite good. Bitterness lingers a bit long for a session though. Very good, but the flavor/palate profile is not quite for me.

Seemingly because of the hops used, theres a lot going on in this beer. Aroma is mild dank earthiness. Taste is citrus, a bit juicy, tropical fruit, that peppery spice, really well-balanced malt sweetness and a bit of earthiness with a mild citrus rind bitterness that sticks to your tongue, but doesnt overpower. Really good stuff. Ill get more if I see it again.

The cheap lager-like aroma told me "uh oh!" right off the bat, but it doesnt taste as bad as it smells (being an IPA). Palate is very light and watery. I get the agave in the taste. I like agave a lot, so thats pleasant. The malt / hops balance is off badly, with almost no malt kicking in with the not-as-good-as-it-could-be juicy citrus hops. Still, those hops are juicy citrus, which is nice, but that bad aroma overshadows all else.

I like this better than "regular" Soul Style, though Im obviously in the minority. Tangerine on the aroma for certain. I dont get a lot of tangerine or sweetness in the taste, but thats fine. Nicely balanced, the citrus juice and rind mild punch is nice against the hops and malt. Id love to try a grapefruit Soul Style after trying this.
beer_name: Green Flash Tangerine Soul Style IPA

review_blob: Aroma is a bit of licorice, roasty grain. Taste is licorice, dark chocolate, coffee and that molasses tangy sweetness. Lots of dried, dark fruit. A bit boozy for my tastes. I think it gets lots more complex as it warms. Good stuff.

Whiskey on the aroma in a big way. The whiskey flavor is less prevalent than I was expecting, but I pick up the rye flavor and spice. Very well balanced with the whiskey/malt sweetness pairing well with the toned down hops bitterness. A colleague put it well, its almost like a barrel aged, sweet rye double IPA. Not boozy to me at all, and Im usually sensitive to that. Yummy.
beer_name: Double Bastard Ale in the Rye

review_blob: I like this better than I thought I would. Aroma is lots of tropical fruit and some grassiness. The taste isnt on par with the aroma, but is still quite decent. Lots of lemon at first, which tones down with subsequent sips. Then citrus rind and malt sweetness. Its OK, but not worth a try unless you like trying Illinois brews so you can check them off your list.

Ever so slightly murky dark golden color with almost no head. Aroma is citrus hops and some earthiness. Taste is sweet, bready malt at first, then mild citrus rind hops with some pine, pineapple, and then it turns grassy. Some peppery spice as well. Palate is heavier than most IPAs, almost to DIPA territory. Very drinkable and fairly unique.

Wonder if mine is a bit old? Taste is semi-normal IPA bready malt and citrus rind and pine hops bitterness and flavor, lemon, slightly grassy and an almost weird vegetal dominates at the end, with the hops and lemon bitterness hanging around. Really weird. Oh well.
Aroma is lost on my stuffed sinuses. Medium dark golden color. Flavor is bready and slightly sweet malt, pine and citrus rind hops, some earthiness. Palate is perfect and slightly juicy. Very good.

Dark orange-yellow, quite cloudy, big head. Aroma is sugars and dried apricots. Quite yummy considering Im not a big-time Belgian fan. Not very sour, nice hops bitterness, I can feel the ABV a little bit, sweet orange and apricot. Quite well carbonated. Very good.
beer_name: Ommegang 2015 Belgian Independence Day Dry-Hopped Tripel

review_blob: A beer buddy shared this, and I didnt check the bottle for a date, but it seems old. High carbonation. Light hops and strong malt aroma. Taste is roasted grain, phenolic / citrus hops, very dry with very little sweetness. Palate feels very lightweight - like something is missing. Not terrible, but not good either.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: Bourbon is crazy in the aroma. The taste is more of the same, with coffee, dark chocolate, dark dried fruit and molasses. ABV is quite obvious and a bit much for me. A decent example of a bourbon barrel aged IS, but not the best Ive had.
beer_name: Port Brewing Santas Little Helper - Bourbon Barrel

review_blob: This is closer to a "regular" IPA than any other session IPA Ive tried. Medium dark golden color. Aroma - lost on my stuffed sinuses. Taste is very intense for a session - lots of pine and citrus rind hops flavor and bitterness, with a near-perfect malt balance. Heaviest palate of any other session Ive tried. It should go very well with food, given its strong hops flavor and bitterness. Very, very good.

I dont have barleywines too often,so take my opinions with a grain of salt. Lots of caramel, toffee, sweetness thats not cloying, minor bitterness. Quite easy drinking for a barleywine. As per usual for this style, the ABV is quite obvious.

Man, all I get from the aroma is booze. Taste is nice: juicy citrus and tropical fruit, a little caramel, nicely tamed citrus rind and pine hops bitterness and a nearly perfect malt balance. ABV is way to obvious too me and makes this beer quite warming. Would be better if the booze taste was toned back in some way, but overall its good.
UPDATED: JAN 19, 2016
beer_name: Evil Twin / 7venth Sun Citra Sunshine Slacker

review_blob: When I looked this up here before tasting it, I was expecting something quite mediocre at best. I like it better than its rating. Earthy aroma. Flavor is earthy, floral hopes with a tiny bit of dank. Mildly bitter, with enough sweetness to balance it nicely. Fairly dry on the finish, which is a bit off-putting. Its OK.
beer_name: Green Flash Pacific Gem Single Hop Pale Ale

review_blob: Wonderful juicy citrus aroma. Citrus in the taste is not as juicy, more like rind with a little pepper spice. Nice malt balance and a medium mouth feel. Really good stuff.
beer_name: Castle Danger Mosaic Fresh Hop IPA

review_blob: Aroma is malt and citrus. Taste is sweet with juicy orange and dry lemon. Most of the bitterness seems to come from that lemony-ness. Nicely balanced. Palate is a bit heavier than most APAs, which is just fine with me, juicy, maybe a bit oily. The lemon is a bit forward for my tastes, but this is an excellent APA, a style Im typically not a huge fan of.
beer_name: Toppling Goliath Light Speed Pale Ale

review_blob: Perhaps my palate is tainted by the 51st Ward The Krispy Karl I just sampled. This is very hoppy, but the malt character just isnt there. Not well balanced at all. Take my review with a grain of salt, since my experience is atypical it seems.

Wow, not a very good stout at all. The nose says "barrel aged" and is nice. The taste is OK, some roasty grain, a bit of coffee and a tiny, tiny, tiny bit of dark chocolate. Pleasantly hoppy for a stout. Where this falls flat on its face is in the palate....its got the consistency of water, theres practically nothing there. Totally ruins the experience. Hey, at least I can say I tried it.
beer_name: 51st Ward The Krispy Karl Imperial Stout

review_blob: This is one of the most complex beers Ive tasted. Aroma is tropical fruit, some chili and pepper spice. Taste is where this thing gets crazy. At first its almost onion-y, then a bit of spice, earthiness and then grapefruit and orange. Not particularly bitter for an IPA. The earthiness sticks to your tongue for quite a while. Enjoyable, though most certainly not an everyday beer....you need to sip this one to really enjoy it I think.
Ive got a cold and the aroma was still amazing - grapefruit, pineapple, tangerine. The taste is mild grapefruit, tangerine and nearly perfectly balanced malt sweetness. A very "juicy" beer. Yummy!

Mine is a year old, thanks to a blind build of a six pack on my part. So, Ill be gentle. Super carbonated Much of the roasty malt, dark chocolate and coffee are gone. Not a ton of hops flavor or bitterness. Still, I see bits of what made this a good one.
beer_name: Clown Shoes Hoppy Feet Black IPA
